entry.title: Hot, Dry Conditions to Persist Through Weekend (Blue Bay Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: Confederated Salish & Kootenai Division of Fire News Release For Immediate Release September 1, 2017 POLSON, Mont. – Weather remains a big concern for firefighters as the Labor Day weekend approaches. Temperatures 10 to 20 degrees above normal, together with low relative humidity and wind, will test the work firefighters have recently completed on the Blue Bay Fire and other fires burning on the Flathead Reservation. At the Blue Bay Fire, containment lines held well during the past several days of hot, windy conditions. Acreage remains at 490 acres and containment is 80 percent. Smoldering and creeping continue to be the predominant fire behavior. Firefighters are addressing any hot spots they encounter while improving firelines. At this time, no additional community meetings are planned unless significant fire activity occurs. Strong winds at the 630-acre Upper Midway Fire near Ravalli pushed flames across containment lines at one location yesterday, but helicopters assisted...

entry.title: Air Quality Smoke report, Libery Fire, Sept. 1, 2017 (Liberty Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: Smoke: Westerly flow will remain aloft behind yesterday’s frontal passage, which will create breezy afternoon and evening winds’ from the west. Active fire behavior is possible, especially in areas that have been blanketed in smoke the last several days. Yesterday, Rice Ridge, Liberty, and Alice Creek added 3,667 acres, 609 acres and 153 acres respectively. Fire: Westerly winds will continue to improve areas that have been blanketed by smoke, however the clear air will also allow more fire activity. Seeley Lake will continue to have Hazardous AQ in the morning followed by better AQ in the afternoon. Condon, Rainy Lake, Clearwater, and Lincoln maybe impacted by blowing smoke this afternoon and could be USG overall, while Arlee and Potomac should have moderate conditions today. Other: High pressure and poor smoke dispersion will return this weekend. Anticipate reduced roadway visibility (AM) especially if RH recovers to+70% (mid- elevation valleys). For additional information...

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for September 1 2017 (Sunrise Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: Smoke: Overall Friday is best represented by “Good” to “Moderate” for air quality. Smoke is expected to filter back into valley locations overnight. Air quality for the weekend is expected to degrade. Fire: The Sunrise fire is located 11 miles SE of Superior, MT adjacent to I-90. Southwest portion of the fire continues to back and flank. Minimal fire growth has been observed and an increase in acreage is not expected on the Sunrise fire. Other: Slightly cooler temperatures Friday accompanied by breezy west winds on the ridgetops. A strong ridge of high pressure will re-establish itself across the Western United States through the upcoming weekend brining record high temperatures and continued dry conditions. entry.title: Air Quality Report for 9-1-2017 (Rice Ridge Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: Smoke: The hot, stagnant conditions from the last few days will give way to critical fire weather today for dry thunderstorms with gusty outflow winds. This will be followed by a dry cold front that should pass through the area beginning this evening bringing increased westerly winds. Active fire behavior, with the potential for rapid growth is possible. Yesterday, Rice Ridge and Liberty added 1,560 acres and 529 acres respectively. Fire: As the stable conditions break down there should be a slight clearing of smoke later today and into the evening, however this will be slow to materialize and variable in terms of the locations due to the erratic nature of the winds associated the dry thunderstorms. As the cold front moves through this evening and tomorrow, accumulated smoke should start to clear but this could be followed by new smoke. Seeley Lake will remain Hazardous and the rest of the sites will remain in the Unhealthy to USG range. Other: Critical fire weather will continue...

entry.title: Rice Ridge Fire Update 9-1-2017 (Rice Ridge Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: A community meeting will be held tonight, September 1, at 6:00 p.m. at the Ovando Elementary School. This event will not be live streamed. Location: Approximately1.4 miles northeast of Seeley Lake Montana Cause: Lightning caused on July 24, 2017 Fire Size and Containment: 37,032 acres and 18% contained Total Personnel: 729 Yesterday: Crews held fire growth at critical locations across the perimeter despite yesterday’s red flag warning. entry.title: SPERRY CHALET WAS LOST AND FIREFIGHTERS ARE SAFE (Sprague Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: Thursday afternoon at approximately 6:00 pm, the main building at the Sperry Chalet was lost to the Sprague Fire. A highly skilled group of firefighters were staged at the Sperry Chalet over the last week. Those firefighters had an extensive hose lay, sprinkler, and pump system installed to protect all of the structures associated with the Chalet. The high winds experienced Thursday afternoon pushed the fire to the north and east. The firefighters were supported by 4 helicopters and made a valiant stand to save the structure. They were unsuccessful in saving the main Sperry Chalet. The firefighters remain on site, ARE SAFE, and are actively engaged in protecting the remaining structures. The Sprague Fire perimeter is now estimated at 4,646 acres after a second Red Flag Warning day. entry.summary: POLSON, Mont. – The National Weather Service has issued a Red Flag Warning for western Montana in effect from 1 p.m. until 9 p.m. High temperatures, winds gusting to 30 miles per hour and low relative humidities are expected. Four lightning strikes hit the Flathead Reservation yesterday and more lightning is possible today. Red Flag Warnings indicate there is high potential for fire combustion, and for any new or existing fires to spread rapidly. During this period of critical fire weather, firefighters will continue to secure and hold firelines on the Blue Bay Fire, as well as monitor unburned areas outside of containment lines for spot fires. Acreage remains steady at 490 acres but containment has increased to 80 percent. With the increased potential for rapid fire spread, some resources on the Blue Bay Fire have been identified for initial attack. entry.summary: Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. Mike Almas’ Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team (IMT) is managing the incident. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages. Fire managers will hold a public meeting jointly for both the Sapphire Complex and the Meyers Fire TONIGHT at 5:30 p.m. at the Granite County High School library. Little Hogback Fire: 30,929 acres, 30% contained. Wednesday, the fire continued to back downhill along the southwestern flank between upper Sheep Gulch and Capron Creek, resulting in the evacuation of three structures in Capron Creek drainage, along Rock Creek Road. Fire managers continue to seek opportunities to complete indirect line and secure firelines along the southwest corner where fire intensity and treacherous terrain continue to hamper containment efforts. entry.title: Another Red Flag Warning in Effect for the Sprague Fire Area (Sprague Fire Wildfire)
entry.summary: A red flag warning is in effect today. With low relative humidity and breezy winds, another critical fire weather day is expected Thursday. With the red flag warning and the steep, rugged terrain that makes up much of the area, fire managers are focusing on firefighter safety as the number one priority. Fire managers will continue to concentrate on structure protection and fuels reduction around park service facilities. The Sprague Fire perimeter is now estimated at 2,097 acres. An infrared flight on Tuesday night reported a growth of 522 acres primarily on the southwest flank. Firefighters continue to reduce fuels around structures and utilize helicopter bucket drops as needed, particularly in the Snyder Creek and Sperry Chalet areas. The fire did cross Snyder Creek on the northeast tip last evening. entry.title: Emergency Fire Closure - Bitteroot National Forest (Nelson Creek Wildfire)
entry.summary: The Bitterroot National Forest has an Emergency Fire Closure in place due to the Nelson Creek Fire on the West Fork Ranger District. The closure includes Gemmell Creek Road #5633 at its junction with Nez Perce Road and Barn Draw Road #373 at its junction with State Highway 473 - West Fork Road. The purpose of this order to protect the public from potential harm from wildfires and firefighting operations associated with the Nelson Creek Fire.
